conclusion: Understanding the problem about light passing through a semi-cylindrical object.
Semi-cylinder with radius R, points A, O, and C labeled; O is the center of the flat side.
Light enters along axis OA from the left, moved to point C at distance \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}R\) from O.
Point C is not on the circumference since its distance from O is \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}R\).
Visualizing semi-cylinder with diameter A to O, curved part is a semicircle with radius R.
Reconsidering position of C, possibly not on curved surface but somewhere else.
Light initially along OA, moved to point C at distance \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}R\) from O.
Considering C as a point on the axis OA extended beyond O, but that seems incorrect.
Possibly C is a point on the flat surface, but unclear.
Key step illustration shows points A, B, C, O, with arrows indicating light path.
Light enters at A, refracts at B on curved surface, possibly reflects or refracts at C.
At point C, no more light rays emitted from the right side of the object.
At point C, light undergoes total internal reflection, angle of incidence equals critical angle.
